articles.title: SEPTEMBER 1985
articles.summary: This document lists the astronomical events and meetings scheduled for September and October 1985. Highlights include general meetings featuring equipment/slide nights and a presentation by Dr. Jack Marling on observing from Mauna Kea. The schedule also details several outdoor star parties, an indoor star party, a regional conference, and board meetings.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The AANC conference has been relocated to Fremont Peak State Park for a picnic and star party, featuring talks and observing sessions. Separately, the Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA) successfully raised over $15,000 from a telescope sale, funding the ongoing construction of an observatory for a 30-inch telescope, which is now seeking volunteers. The article also reminds readers about membership renewals for the SJAA.

articles.title: JACK MARLING ON MAUNA KEA
articles.summary: Dr. Jack Marling of Lumicon will speak to the SJAA on October 5th about his experiences observing and performing astrophotography at the 14,000 ft Mauna Kea observatory. He will discuss the unique challenges of high-altitude observing and his pioneering color astrophotography of planetary nebulae using the Air Force 24" cassegrain telescope. The event will take place at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building.

articles.title: AUGUST EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: The 'August Ephemeris' has been published, with special thanks extended to its numerous contributors. The publication has received excellent reviews, although contributor Kevin Medlock noted a correction regarding the size of a space telescope mentioned within.

articles.title: DEEP SKY NOTES - SEPTEMBER
articles.summary: This article, "Deep Sky Notes - September," serves as a guide for observing the often-overlooked constellation Equuleus, detailing its multiple star systems and faint deep-sky objects. Despite Equuleus being obscure, small, and lacking bright targets, the author provides specific observing notes, coordinates, and historical context for several triple stars and galaxies, encouraging amateur astronomers to explore this challenging region.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document, titled "ASTRO ADS," features classified advertisements for buying and selling astronomical equipment. It includes listings for various telescopes, such as Dobsonian, Newtonian, and C8 models, along with numerous accessories like eyepieces, filters, and mount components. Contact information is provided for individuals seeking to buy or sell these items.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The Perseid Meteor Shower in August significantly underperformed expectations, with hourly meteor counts on August 12th reported at 20-30, well below the normal rate of 40, according to observations by the San Jose Astronomical Association. This led to speculation, including an editor's note, that the shower's actual peak might have occurred earlier on August 11th, where bright meteors were observed.

articles.title: PUBLIC VIEWING SESSIONS OF HALLEY'S COMET FROM SAN JOSE.
articles.summary: Don Machholz is organizing public viewing sessions of Halley's Comet in San Jose during November, December, and January, collaborating with the City of San Jose Parks Dept. The events will take place in public parks on specific dates each month, aiming to provide a rare opportunity for the public to observe the comet, despite anticipated challenging viewing conditions due to light pollution. The article serves as a call for volunteers to assist in showing the comet through telescopes.

articles.title: BY: ROBERT FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article reports on several contemporary space activities, including the Challenger Space Lab II mission's successful, though initially troubled, completion with solar data collection. It also covers the upcoming Discovery shuttle launch with communication satellites, the first commercial sale of space-processed latex spheres, and various Soviet space program updates like docking an unmanned platform with Salyut and launching a biology satellite with a NASA sensor. Additionally, it details the destruction of NASA's Galileo-2 research aircraft by fire and Lockheed's development of a 25kW power module.

articles.title: CONFLICT ON SHUTTLE PRICING
articles.summary: Congress and President Reagan are in conflict over Space Shuttle launch pricing. Congress recommends a $71 million price starting October 1988, while President Reagan proposes a $74 million auction with limited availability. Congress fears Reagan's policy would undermine U.S. competitiveness against European rivals like Ariane and is threatening legislative action.

articles.title: AIR FORCE BUYS UP DELTA LAUNCHERS
articles.summary: The Air Force has purchased the final three Delta launchers. These boosters are designated for the launch of Strategic Defense Initiative payloads.

articles.title: AIR FORCE SEES NEED FOR SHUTTLE REPLACEMENT IN 1990'S
articles.summary: The Air Force anticipates a need for a Space Shuttle replacement in the 1990s, advocating for a family of boosters to meet projected launch requirements. NASA estimates 30 flights per year by 1992, with significant demand from NASA, NOAA, and the Department of Defense, far exceeding the current Shuttle's planned capability of 17 flights annually with four orbiters.

articles.title: THERMOELECTRIC CONVERSION CHOSEN FOR SPACE POWER SYSTEM
articles.summary: The second phase of the SP-100 program will focus on thermoelectric conversion technology for its space power system, aiming to generate hundreds of kilowatts. This decision follows Phase I, which also investigated thermionic conversion and Stirling engines.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article provides updates on several comets, reporting the recent recovery of three faint comets (Giclas, Whipple, and Shajn-Schaldach) previously observed in 1978/79. It notes that comet Giacobini-Zinner is reaching its brightest point this month and Halley's comet has reappeared and is expected to brighten significantly. Conversely, Comet Machholz is presumed to have disintegrated after a close solar approach.

articles.title: PERIODIC COMET GIACOBINI-ZINNER (1984e)
articles.summary: Periodic Comet Giacobini-Zinner (1984e) currently displays a short tail and is set for an encounter with the USA space probe ICE on September 11. Days later, it will appear near Halley's Comet due to a line-of-sight effect, despite being much closer to Earth. The article provides an ephemeris detailing its right ascension, declination, elongation, and magnitude from late August to mid-October.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND-HALLEY'S
articles.summary: Halley's Comet has been successfully "recovered" as it emerges from behind the sun, though initially fainter than anticipated, it is expected to brighten significantly. The article provides detailed observational data for September, including its positions, magnitudes, and rising times, noting optimal viewing periods and the close pass of Comet Giacobini-Zinner. Additionally, it announces the release of a new children's booklet about Halley's Comet.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT
articles.summary: This article discusses recent observations of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), noting its fading and reduced contrast. The author experimented with various filters, finding that a Lumicon UHC filter unexpectedly improved GRS visibility. Additionally, the text briefly mentions the ease of observing Galilean satellite disks and provides a method for estimating the coma size of Halley's Comet.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PDT
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule of dates and times in Pacific Daylight Time (PDT) when Jupiter's Great Red Spot will be on the meridian. An accompanying editorial note discusses the visibility of Jupiter's moons as disks, emphasizing the critical role of atmospheric seeing over telescope aperture, and speculates on reasons for the Great Red Spot's color fading. It concludes by noting that Jupiter's higher declination will improve future observing conditions for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE IN CYGNUS
articles.summary: This article serves as an observing guide to over 30 planetary nebulae found in the constellation Cygnus, specifically focusing on the western portion. It provides detailed advice on selecting the appropriate observing filters based on factors like light pollution, magnification, and exit pupil, recommending specific filter types for different conditions. The text also mentions a forthcoming table that will list west Cygnus planetaries with observational data such as coordinates, size, magnitude, and surface brightness.

articles.title: DESCRIPTION OF OBJECTS
articles.summary: This article details the visual observation of several planetary nebulae, including Campbell's Star, Abell 61, NGC 6826, NGC 6883, Henize 1-4, and Kohoutek 3-73. For each object, the text provides historical context, unique observational characteristics (like filter recommendations and "blinking" effects), and specific observer reports detailing visibility with various telescope and filter configurations. The author also highlights instances of potentially being the first to visually observe certain nebulae.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE in WEST CYGNUS
articles.summary: This article details several planetary nebulae in West Cygnus, offering observational guidance and notes on their discovery and visual characteristics. It highlights specific challenges, first visual sightings, and recommended equipment like Oxygen-III filters and various telescopes for successful viewing of these faint deep-sky objects.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE in WEST CYGNUS
articles.summary: This document provides a catalog of planetary nebulae located in the western region of the Cygnus constellation. For each celestial object, it lists critical astronomical data including its 2000.0 coordinates, size, overall magnitude, surface brightness, and the magnitude of its central nucleus. The information appears to serve as a reference for observers or researchers interested in these specific nebulae.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document outlines the details for monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" held by the SJAA at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. It provides the full address and detailed driving directions from Hwy. 17 South, noting that meetings commence at 8 PM.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is a popular observing site for the SJAA, located on Mt. Hamilton Road. The article provides detailed driving directions and important information regarding gate access, including a combination lock (4565) to be used after sunset. It also mentions another observing area further up the road within the park.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to Henry Coe State Park, including the route from Hwy 101 and specific landmarks. It outlines access instructions for an observing site, noting a locked gate with a club combination (4565), and emphasizes safety protocols like relocking the gate and using parking lights only after dark, along with advice for late arrivals.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park for visitors attending a San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) Coulter Camp. It highlights the location of the SJAA setup within the park and reminds attendees about parking light etiquette after dark.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the officers of an organization, including the President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer. For each officer, it provides their name, address, and telephone number, serving as a contact directory for the organization's leadership.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document lists the members of a Board of Directors along with their respective phone numbers. It serves as a contact roster for the individuals holding directorial positions within an organization.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS EDITOR:
articles.summary: This document introduces an "Ephemeris Editor" and provides contact information for its author, John P. Gleason. Due to the limited content provided, no further details regarding the editor's functionality or purpose are available.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership tiers, including adult, junior, and options with or without a Sky & Telescope subscription, along with their respective costs. The form provides fields for personal information and instructions on how to submit the application to the treasurer, Jack Peterson, either in person or via mail.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gather information on individuals' astronomical interests, such as astrophotography or deep-sky observation, and whether they own a telescope. It also inquires about areas where respondents feel qualified to help others. The page includes mailing details for the 'SJAA EPHEMERIS,' suggesting it's part of a newsletter or publication from the San Jose Astronomical Association.
